courseDescription: Topics include: data description, elementary probability, binomial and normal distributions, interval estimation, hypothesis testing, and correlation. The role of probability in inference is emphasized.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of binomial and normal distributions

courseDescription: A general probability and statistics course designed specifically to accommodate the needs of school teachers and health professionals.  Topics include: descriptive statistics, basic probability, discrete random variables, continuous random variables, interval estimation, regression and correlation, hypothesis testing, and applications.  (May not be used to satisfy the upper-division elective requirement of the math major program.)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Application of statistical concepts in professional fields
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Interpretation of regression and correlation data

courseDescription: Topics include measures of location, dispersion, and strength of relationship; parametric and nonparametric tests of location; one-way analysis of variance; complete block designs; simple and multiple regression; correlation; measures of association for categorical data. Microsoft EXCEL will be used extensively as an aid in data analysis.  Written interpretation of results will be a routine component of daily assignments.
Technical and Digital Skills: Parametric and nonparametric tests of location
Measures of association for categorical data
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Written interpretation of data analysis results

courseTitle: An Introduction to Probability and Statistics
courseDescription: Topics include: descriptive statistics, probability theory and probability distributions, mathematical expectation and its role in decision making, hypothesis testing, point and interval estimation, numerous applications. (Not open to students with credit in STATÂ 331.)

An introduction to probability theory including probability functions, continuous and discrete random variables, combinatorics, special probability distributions, moment generating functions, and limit laws.
Technical and Digital Skills: Handling continuous and discrete random variables
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying limit laws to solve problems

courseDescription: This course will introduce SAS and R, two of the most widely used statistical software packages. This course will cover the basic skills needed for using computer packages to perform a variety of statistical analyses. Topics include data import/export, manipulation, descriptive statistics and visualization, advanced data handling, and the use of statistical computer packages for categorical data analysis, regression analysis, hypothesis testing, and more.
Topics include point and interval estimation, tests of hypotheses, introduction to linear models, likelihood techniques, and regression and correlation analysis.

Sampling from finite populations is discussed. Topics such as simple random sampling, stratified random sampling and ratio and regression estimation are included. Also discussed are aspects of systematic sampling, cluster sampling, and multi-stage sampling.
Technical and Digital Skills: Proficiency in ratio and regression estimation
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to select appropriate sampling method
Analytical thinking in sampling design and execution

courseDescription: Topics include introduction to design of experiments, analysis of variance with a single factor, power and OC curves, and two factors with interactions, random effects models, randomized blocks, Latin square and related designs, introduction to factorial and 2k factorial designs. Statistical software will be used to analyze real life data.
Technical and Digital Skills: Using statistical software for data analysis
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying statistical methods to real life data

courseTitle: Applied Regression and Time Series Analysis
courseDescription: Topics include introduction to regression and model building, simple linear regression, multiple regression, logistic regression, and simple time series, residual analysis, selection of variables, model adequacy checking, regression on dummy variables, analysis of covariance, regression analysis of time series data, and applications of these techniques to real life data using statistical software. Pre- or
Technical and Digital Skills: Regression analysis of time series data
Applications of these techniques to real life data using statistical software
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Interpretation and analysis of statistical results
Identification and selection of relevant variables
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordination in the use of statistical software

courseDescription: This course will introduce basic statistical concepts and methods used in clinical trials. Topics include phase-I trial designs including 3+3 and CRM dose-finding designs; phase-II trial designs including Gehanâs two-stage and Simonâs two-stage designs; phase-III trial designs including parallel, group allocation, cross-over, and factorial designs; randomization; sample size and power calculation; adaptive trials; and monitoring of trials for safety and efficacy.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of phase-I, II, and III trial designs
Knowledge of 3+3 and CRM dose-finding designs
Knowledge of Gehanâs two-stage and Simonâs two-stage designs
Understanding of parallel, group allocation, cross-over, and factorial designs
Ability to calculate sample size and power
Ability to monitor trials for safety and efficacy
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate complex statistical concepts
Ability to present trial findings effectively
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to problem-solve in the context of trial design and implementation
Understanding of statistical concepts and methods
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ability to manage and monitor clinical trials
Ability to adapt trial designs based on emerging data
Understanding of safety and efficacy monitoring

courseDescription: Topics include nonlinear and generalized linear models, quantitative risk assessment, analysis of stimulus-response and spatially correlated data, methods of combining data from several independent studies.  Regression settings are emphasized where one or more predictor variables are used to make inferences on an outcome variable of interest.  Applications include modeling growth inhibition of organisms exposed to environmental toxins, spatial associations of like species, risk estimation, and spatial prediction.  SAS is used extensively in the course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis of stimulus-response and spatially correlated data
Methods of combining data from several independent studies
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of stimulus-response and spatially correlated data
Methods of combining data from several independent studies
Modeling growth inhibition of organisms exposed to environmental toxins

courseDescription: This course introduces statistical methods for analyzing multivariate and longitudinal data. Topics include multivariate normal distribution, covariance modeling, multivariate linear models, principal components, analysis of continuous response repeated measures, and models for discrete longitudinal data. Emphasis will be on the applications to the biological and health sciences and the use of the statistical software.
Technical and Digital Skills: Statistical methods for multivariate and longitudinal data
Analysis of continuous response repeated measures
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of statistical methods to biological and health sciences

courseDescription: Topics include the theory and applications of binomial tests and rank tests, including the tests of McNemar, Mann-Whitney, Friedman, Kruskal-Wallis, and Smirnov.

Topics include types of categorical data, relative risk and odds ratio measures for 2 x 2 tables, the chi-square and Mantel-Haenszel tests, Fisher's exact test, analysis of sets of 2 x 2 tables using Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel methodology, analysis of I x J and sets of I x J tables for both nominal and ordinal data, logistic regression including the logit and probit models. Emphasis will be on the application of these statistical tools to data related to the health and social sciences. Interpretation of computer output will be stressed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Calculating relative risk and odds ratio measures for 2 x 2 tables
Analyzing sets of tables using Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel methodology
Analyzing I x J and sets of I x J tables for both nominal and ordinal data
Applying logistic regression including the logit and probit models
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of statistical tools to health and social sciences data

courseDescription: This course is designed to help students enhance their personal and professional development through innovation guided by faculty members and professionals. It offers students an opportunity to apply their knowledge of statistics to the development of a new product, business, nonprofit program, or other initiative. The real world experiences that entrepreneurships provide will help students understand how academic knowledge leads to transformations, innovations, and solutions to different types of problems. This course is administered as an independent project for individual students, or as group projects.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of real world business scenarios

courseDescription: This course will introduce SAS and R, two of the most widely used statistical software packages. This course will cover the basic skills needed for using computer packages to perform a variety of statistical analyses. Topics include data import/export, manipulation, descriptive statistics and visualization, advanced data handling, and the use of statistical computer packages for categorical data analysis, regression analysis, hypothesis testing, and more.
Topics include point and interval estimation, tests of hypotheses, introduction to linear models, likelihood techniques, and regression and correlation analysis.

Sampling from finite populations is discussed. Topics such as simple random sampling, stratified random sampling and ratio and regression estimation are included. Also discussed are aspects of systematic sampling, cluster sampling, and multi-stage sampling.

Topics include introduction to design of experiments, analysis of variance with a single factor, power and OC curves, and two factors with interactions, random effects models, randomized blocks, Latin square and related designs, introduction to factorial and 2k factorial designs. Statistical software will be used to analyze real life data.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis of variance with a single factor
Understanding of power and OC curves
Knowledge of Latin square and related designs
Introduction to factorial and 2k factorial designs
Use of statistical software for data analysis
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical thinking through analysis of variance

courseTitle: Applied Regression and Time Series Analysis
courseDescription: Topics include introduction to regression and model building, simple linear regression, multiple regression, logistic regression, and simple time series, residual analysis, selection of variables, model adequacy checking, regression on dummy variables, analysis of covariance, regression analysis of time series data, and applications of these techniques to real life data using statistical software.
Technical and Digital Skills: Regression analysis of time series data
Use of statistical software for data analysis
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to identify appropriate variables for regression

courseDescription: This course will introduce basic statistical concepts and methods used in clinical trials. Topics include phase-I trial designs including 3+3 and CRM dose-finding designs; phase-II trial designs including Gehanâs two-stage and Simonâs two-stage designs; phase-III trial designs including parallel, group allocation, cross-over, and factorial designs; randomization; sample size and power calculation; adaptive trials; and monitoring of trials for safety and efficacy.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of phase-I trial designs including 3+3 and CRM dose-finding designs
Knowledge of phase-II trial designs including Gehanâs two-stage and Simonâs two-stage designs
Knowledge of phase-III trial designs including parallel, group allocation, cross-over, and factorial designs
Ability to calculate sample size and power
Monitoring of trials for safety and efficacy
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of safety and efficacy data

courseDescription: Topics include nonlinear and generalized linear models, quantitative risk assessment, analysis of stimulus-response and spatially correlated data, methods of combining data from several independent studies.  Regression settings are emphasized where one or more predictor variables are used to make inferences on an outcome variable of interest.  Applications include modeling growth inhibition of organisms exposed to environmental toxins, spatial associations of like species, risk estimation, and spatial prediction.  SAS is used extensively in the course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis of stimulus-response and spatially correlated data
Methods of combining data from several independent studies

courseDescription: This course introduces statistical methods for analyzing multivariate and longitudinal data. Topics include multivariate normal distribution, covariance modeling, multivariate linear models, principal components, analysis of continuous response repeated measures, and models for discrete longitudinal data. Emphasis will be on the applications to the biological and health sciences and the use of the statistical software.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis of continuous response repeated measures
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Application of statistical methods to biological and health sciences

courseDescription: Topics include the theory and applications of binomial tests and rank tests, including the tests of McNemar, Mann-Whitney, Friedman, Kruskal-Wallis, and Smirnov.

Topics include types of categorical data, relative risk and odds ratio measures for 2 x 2 tables, the chi-square and Mantel-Haenszel tests, Fisher's exact test, analysis of sets of 2 x 2 tables using Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel methodology, analysis of I x J and sets of I x J tables for both nominal and ordinal data, logistic regression including the logit and probit models. Emphasis will be on the application of these statistical tools to data related to the health and social sciences. Interpretation of computer output will be stressed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analyzing sets of 2 x 2 tables using Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel methodology
Analyzing I x J and sets of I x J tables for both nominal and ordinal data
Applying logistic regression including the logit and probit models
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Calculating relative risk and odds ratio measures for 2 x 2 tables
Application of statistical tools to health and social sciences data

courseDescription: The advanced study of selected topics.

courseTitle: Probability Models for Data Science and Analytics
courseDescription: This course will serve as an introduction for modeling data using probability and statistical methods. Topics include basic concepts of probability, Bayes theorem, frequently-occurring discrete and continuous probability distributions, as well as how to simulate data from these distributions. Basic properties of the probability distributions will be discussed, which will provide an insight into the use of these distributions in data science. R and/or Python will be the computation software used in class. This course is open only for students enrolled in the M.S. degree program in Data Science and Analytics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of frequently-occurring discrete and continuous probability distributions
Command of R and Python programming languages
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Insight generation from data using probability distributions

courseTitle: Statistical Tools for Data Science and Analytics
courseDescription: This course will cover statistical tools for data exploration. Topics taught include descriptive statistics, correlation, confidence intervals, linear and logistic regressions, t-test for one and two samples, and analysis of variance. For analyzing categorical data, students will study contingency tables, odds ratios for measuring association, and chi-square tests for testing independence. The course will also introduce principal components and clustering methods to analyze multivariate data. R and/or Python software for computing various statistics for real data analysis will be used. This course is open only for students enrolled in the M.S. degree program in Data Science and Analytics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and application of confidence intervals
T-test application for one and two samples
Calculation and interpretation of odds ratios
Clustering methods for multivariate data analysis

courseDescription: Intended for graduate students in all academic disciplines; not available for credit to graduate students in the Department of Mathematics and Statistics.  Topics include descriptive statistics, probability computations, estimation, hypothesis testing, linear regression, analysis of variance and categorical data analysis.  Emphasis will be on statistical analysis of data arising in a research setting.  The rationale for selecting methods to address research questions will be emphasized.  Examples will be given from the health sciences, social sciences, engineering, education and other application areas.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interpreting data from various disciplines (health sciences, social sciences, engineering, education)
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Selecting appropriate statistical methods for research questions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading statistical analysis in a research setting

courseDescription: An introduction to probability. Topics include axiomatic foundations of probability, conditional probability, Bayes formula, random variables, density and mass functions, stochastic independence, expectation, moment generating functions, transformations, common families of distributions, multiple random variables, covariance and correlation, multivariate distributions, convergence concepts, law of large numbers, limit theorems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of axiomatic foundations of probability
Application of conditional probability and Bayes formula
Understanding of density and mass functions
Calculation and interpretation of expectation and moment generating functions
Understanding of common families of distributions
Application of law of large numbers
Understanding and application of limit theorems

courseDescription: An introduction to statistical inference. Principles of data reduction, sufficiency, completeness, ancillary, likelihood principle, point estimation, method of moments, maximum likelihood and Bayes estimation, Cramer-Rao inequality, hypothesis testing, likelihood ratio tests, Bayesian tests, most powerful tests, Neyman-Pearson Lemma, interval estimates, pivotal quantities, asymptotic evaluations, consistency and asymptotic relative efficiency.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and application of statistical inference
Understanding and application of likelihood ratio tests
Understanding and application of interval estimates
Understanding of consistency and asymptotic relative efficiency
Understanding and application of pivotal quantities
Understanding and application of asymptotic evaluations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing and organizing large data sets

courseDescription: This course examines the principles and concepts of time series and forecasting.  Study includes theory, methods, and model parameter estimation taking into account correlation and autocorrelation structures with data applications from pollution, economics, seasonal trends, and the stock market.  Notions of autoregressive, moving, average, stationary and nonstationary ARIMA models will be discussed.  The multivariate version and state-space models will also be introduced. Simulation of time series data will be discussed in depth.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of time series principles and concepts
Understanding of correlation and autocorrelation structures
Application of time series concepts to real world data from various fields
Understanding of autoregressive, moving average, stationary and nonstationary ARIMA models
Knowledge of multivariate versions and state-space models
Ability to simulate time series data
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to explain complex time series concepts
Ability to present data applications from various fields
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to analyze time series data
Ability to detect patterns and trends in time series data
Ability to apply forecasting methods to solve problems

courseDescription: Under the guidance of a faculty member in the Department of Mathematics and Statistics, the student will undertake a significant data analysis problem in a scientific setting outside the department.  A written report and/or public presentation of results will be required.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with faculty members and external scientific settings

courseDescription: This course is intended to teach statistical consulting techniques to graduate students in statistics. Students are expected to work on statistical consulting problems brought by faculty and graduate students in various fields.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of statistical tools and software
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with faculty and students from various fields

courseDescription: Topics include theory of least squares regression, multiple linear regression (including its matrix formulation), transformations and weighting, diagnostics for leverage and influence, polynomial and indicator regression model, multi-collinearity, variable selection and model building, validation of regression models, introduction to nonlinear regression, robust regression, regression for time series data, and applications of these techniques using statistical software.
Technical and Digital Skills: Regression diagnostics for leverage and influence

courseTitle: Advanced Design and Analysis of Experiments
courseDescription: Topics include blocking and confounding in factorial designs, power, balanced incomplete block designs, fractional factorial designs, factors with mixed levels, response surface methods and designs, Latin and Graeco-Latin square designs, optimality criterion, examples of optimal designs, experiments with random factors, nested and split-plot designs, analysis of covariance, robust designs. Statistical software will be used to analyze real life data.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of balanced incomplete block designs
Application of response surface methods and designs
Creating Latin and Graeco-Latin square designs
Use of statistical software for data analysis
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Dealing with experiments with random factors

courseDescription: This course introduces basic concepts and methods for analyzing survival time data obtained from following individuals until occurrence of an event or their loss to follow-up. Topics include survival and hazard functions, censoring, Kaplan-Meier estimation, log-rank and related tests, Cox proportional hazards model, and the extended Cox model for time-varying covariates, and parametric models. Both SAS and R software will be used to analyze survival data.
Technical and Digital Skills: Extended Cox model for time-varying covariates
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Working with loss to follow-up data

courseDescription: This course is intended to develop the ability to perform statistical computing using R statistical software. The course will cover programming topics (vectorization, data input and output, data manipulation, and building R packages), statistical and computational methods (visualization, optimization, simulation, and resampling), and direct integration and dynamic reporting using R markdown. Additionally, this course will include the use of high-performance computing resources at Old Dominion University. This is a finishing course for statisticians and professionals willing to pursue a career in statistical programming and simulation.
Technical and Digital Skills: Statistical computing using R statistical software
Programming in R (vectorization, data input and output, data manipulation)
Statistical and computational methods (visualization, optimization, simulation, resampling)
Direct integration and dynamic reporting using R markdown

courseDescription: Student participation for credit based on academic relevance of the work experience, criteria, and evaluative procedures as formally determined by the department and the cooperative education program prior to the semester in which the work experience is to take place.
Advanced study of selected topics.

Topics to be covered include convergence concepts, limit theorems, large sample theory, asymptotic distributions, decision theory, minimax, admissibility, Bayes estimates, generalized Neyman-Pearson Lemma, uniformly most powerful tests, unbiased tests, invariant tests, and Bayesian tests.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Using asymptotic distributions to analyze large sample data
Applying Neyman-Pearson Lemma for hypothesis testing

courseDescription: Topics include the multivariate normal distribution, graphical display of multivariate data and tests for normality, Hotelling's T2, multivariate analysis of variance (MANOVA) and regression, profile analysis, growth curve models, canonical correlation analysis, principal components, factor models, clustering, and discriminant analysis. All methods are implemented using the SAS statistical software.
Technical and Digital Skills: Implementing statistical methods using SAS statistical software
Conducting multivariate analysis of variance (MANOVA) and regression
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Interpreting results of multivariate normal distribution
Applying and interpreting results of discriminant analysis

courseDescription: This course will discuss sequential and adaptive designs for clinical trials; the statistical properties and challenges these designs engender; and the advantages and disadvantages of utilizing sequential and adaptive designs compared to a standard, fixed-sample design.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of sequential and adaptive designs for clinical trials
Knowledge of statistical properties of clinical trials
Ability to evaluate the advantages and disadvantages of different trial designs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of statistical properties and challenges

courseDescription: This course will discuss sequential and adaptive designs for clinical trials; the statistical properties and challenges these designs engender; and the advantages and disadvantages of utilizing sequential and adaptive designs compared to a standard, fixed-sample design.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of sequential and adaptive designs for clinical trials
Knowledge of statistical properties and challenges induced by these designs
Ability to assess advantages and disadvantages of sequential and adaptive designs compared to a standard, fixed-sample design
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate complex statistical concepts
Capability to articulate pros and cons of different trial designs

courseDescription: Topics include general linear models, weighted least squares (WLS), maximum likelihood (ML), restricted maximum likelihood (REML) methods of estimation, analysis of continuous response repeated measures data, parametric models for covariance structure, generalized estimating equations (GEE) for discrete longitudinal data, marginal, random effects, and transition models. Limitations of existing approaches will be discussed. Emphasis will be on the application of these tools to data related to the biological and health sciences. Methods will be implemented using statistical software.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilization of restricted maximum likelihood (REML) methods
Analysis of continuous response repeated measures data
Application of parametric models for covariance structure
Use of generalized estimating equations (GEE) for discrete longitudinal data
Understanding of marginal, random effects, and transition models
Using statistical software for data analysis
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating statistical results and their implications in the context of biological and health sciences
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and addressing limitations of existing analytical approaches
Applying advanced statistical methods to real-world data
Analyzing continuous and discrete longitudinal data

courseDescription: Topics include multivariate permutation tests, multivariate rank tests, permutation and rank tests for censored data, bootstrap methods, permutation and rank tests for the analysis of multifactor experiments, and nonparametric smoothing methods.
Technical and Digital Skills: Permutation and rank tests for censored data
Permutation and rank tests for the analysis of multifactor experiments

courseDescription: This course will cover statistical models and methods appropriate for analyzing categorical responses, contingency tables, Pearson Chi-square test, Fisherâs Exact test, Mantel-Haenszel test, Cochran-Armitage trend test, independence and conditional independence, Simpsonâs paradox, generalized linear models, logistic and Poisson regression models, matched paired studies, McNemar test, conditional logistic regression model and random effects logistic model for data from matched paired studies, models for multinomial data.
Technical and Digital Skills: Implementing statistical models and methods for categorical responses analysis
Understanding of independence and conditional independence
Implementing logistic and Poisson regression models
Applying random effects logistic model for data from matched paired studies

courseDescription: Seminar.

Topics include the multivariate normal distribution, distributions of quadratic forms, the general linear model, estimability, the Gauss-Markov theorem and general linear hypotheses, analysis of variance (ANOVA) and covariance (ANCOVA) with special attention to unbalanced data, and analysis of mixed effects and variance components models including repeated measures and split-plot designs.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of distributions of quadratic forms
Proficiency in the general linear model
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to analyze mixed effects models
Ability to analyze variance components models
Ability to analyze repeated measures models

courseDescription: Topics to be covered include introduction to measure theoretic probability, properties of group and exponential families, sufficiency, unbiasedness, equivariance, properties of estimators, large sample theory, maximum likelihood estimation, EM algorithm, information inequality, asymptotic optimality.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of properties of group and exponential families
Proficiency in evaluating properties of estimators
Application of the principle of asymptotic optimality
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to identify sufficiency, unbiasedness, and equivariance
Competence in problem-solving using statistical methods
Analytical skills to interpret complex statistical data

courseDescription: Topics to be covered include convergence concepts, limit theorems, large sample theory, asymptotic distributions, decision theory, minimax, admissibility, Bayes estimates, generalized Neyman-Pearson Lemma, uniformly most powerful tests, unbiased tests, invariant tests, and Bayesian tests.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of uniformly most powerful tests
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Using Bayes estimates for hypothesis testing
Applying Neyman-Pearson Lemma in statistical decision making
Implementing uniformly most powerful tests for statistical analysis

courseDescription: Topics include the multivariate normal distribution, graphical display of multivariate data and tests for normality, Hotelling's T2, multivariate analysis of variance (MANOVA) and regression, profile analysis, growth curve models, canonical correlation analysis, principal components, factor models, clustering, and discriminant analysis. All methods are implemented using the SAS statistical software.
Technical and Digital Skills: Multivariate analysis of variance (MANOVA) and regression

courseDescription: This course will discuss sequential and adaptive designs for clinical trials; the statistical properties and challenges these designs engender; and the advantages and disadvantages of utilizing sequential and adaptive designs compared to a standard, fixed-sample design.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of sequential and adaptive designs for clinical trials
Knowledge of statistical properties of trial designs
Assessment of advantages and disadvantages of different trial designs
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presentation of trial design advantages and disadvantages
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in the face of design challenges
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in decision-making for trial designs

courseDescription: This course will discuss sequential and adaptive designs for clinical trials; the statistical properties and challenges these designs engender; and the advantages and disadvantages of utilizing sequential and adaptive designs compared to a standard, fixed-sample design.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of sequential and adaptive designs
Knowledge of statistical properties of clinical trials
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to articulate advantages and disadvantages of different trial designs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing challenges in clinical trial designs
Evaluation of statistical properties in clinical trials

Limitations of existing approaches will be discussed. Emphasis will be on the application of these tools to data related to the biological and health sciences. Knowledge of parametric models for covariance structure
Application of generalized estimating equations (GEE) for discrete longitudinal data
Understanding of marginal, random effects, and transition models
Use of statistical software for data analysis
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to analyze complex biological and health science data

Application of advanced statistical tools to real-world data

courseDescription: Topics include multivariate permutation tests, multivariate rank tests, permutation and rank tests for censored data, bootstrap methods, permutation and rank tests for the analysis of multifactor experiments, and nonparametric smoothing methods.
Technical and Digital Skills: Permutation and rank tests for censored data
Permutation and rank tests for the analysis of multifactor experiments

courseDescription: This course will cover statistical models and methods appropriate for analyzing categorical responses, contingency tables, Pearson Chi-square test, Fisherâs Exact test, Mantel-Haenszel test, Cochran-Armitage trend test, independence and conditional independence, Simpsonâs paradox, generalized linear models, logistic and Poisson regression models, matched paired studies, McNemar test, conditional logistic regression model and random effects logistic model for data from matched paired studies, models for multinomial data.
Technical and Digital Skills: Logistic and Poisson regression models application

courseDescription: This course is a pass/fail course doctoral students may take to maintain active status after successfully passing the candidacy examination.  All doctoral students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour every semester until their graduation.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Maintaining active communication with faculty and peers
